image.altText: Two men wearing navy suits holding budget papers walk outside on a city street

items.synopsis: Labor has made a number of pre-budget announcements, focusing mostly on health, child protection and cost-of-living relief, as the Treasurer Stephen Mullighan announces a $249 million deficit.

title.children: Back to bread and butter — what we know about SA's budget

image.altText: The PwC logo is shown on an office building.

items.synopsis: PricewaterhouseCoopers began work on a top-level consulting contract with the federal government's regulator of tertiary colleges 24 hours before agreeing to acquire a $5.5 million stake in one such college, the controversial Top Education Group.

title.children: PwC worked for tertiary education regulator as it acquired stake in college

image.altText: A man in a jacket sits on a park bench.

items.synopsis: Peter Malinauskas apologises to survivors of child sexual abuse in state care during an address to parliament, including Ki Meekins, who was taken interstate and sexually abused in the 1960s.

title.children: 'Given me my identity back': South Australian abuse survivor thanks premier for apology

image.altText: Liberal Senator David Van

items.synopsis: Senator David Van confirms he took up an offer to move offices away from Senator Lidia Thorpe, after the senator made a complaint about him.

title.children: Liberal senator David Van confirms he moved offices after Lidia Thorpe made complaint

image.altText: A man in glasses and a suit stands between Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags.

items.synopsis: A lease held by the Russian Federation for an embassy close to Parliament House has been cancelled by the federal government.

title.children: Government rushes through law to stop new Russian embassy being built near Parliament House

items.synopsis: It was a Sunday afternoon in Port Arthur in 1996 when the three people Walter Mikac loved most were brutally taken from him.

title.children: Nine days after Walter Mikac lost his entire family, he sent a letter that helped change the course of Australian history

image.altText: A man wearing a black cap fixes the collar of Trump's white jumper.

items.synopsis: Many of the familiar faces that surrounded Donald Trump in his final days in the White House have exited his orbit. But there is one man who remained dutifully by his side — and his loyalty may have made him a target of the FBI.

title.children: How the man who was constantly by Trump’s side ended up in court as his co-defendant

image.altText: Side by side photos of Anthony Albanese, looking up in a green tie, and Donald Trump, looking serious in a red tie

items.synopsis: Two years after Anthony Albanese openly criticised Donald Trump, the prime minister is now being urged to prepare for the very real possibility of his return to the White House, writes David Speers.

title.children: What would another Trump presidency mean for Australia?

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith looks at the camera outside a court building

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happened.

title.children: Ben Roberts-Smith speaks after returning to Australia. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: A pregnant woman using a mobile phone

items.synopsis: Many Australians use phone apps to help track their periods, for convenience, contraception or to better understand fertility and reproductive health, but privacy experts warn they're not without risk.

title.children: Many Australians use period-tracker apps for convenience, but experts warn they could come at a cost

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios hits a ball during the US Open first round against Thanasi Kokkinakis

items.synopsis: Australian tennis star Nick Kyrgios reveals he attended a mental health hospital in 2019, as he battled alcohol and drug abuse. Warning: This story contains themes of self-harm and suicide.

title.children: 'You could tell I was hurting': Kyrgios says he attended mental health hospital after 2019 tournament

image.altText: A composite graphic featuring a financial graph overlaying a photo of two Ezidi men in Toowoomba, Queensland, 2023

items.synopsis: Financial pressure on households has never been higher, and more of us are spending beyond our means than ever before, according to a long-running survey.

title.children: Young families and renters face unprecedented cash flow pressure as financial stress hits new high

image.altText: Aerial view Couran Cove Island resort

items.synopsis: Cheap waterfront properties are listed for sale at Couran Cove near the Gold Coast, but the real estate ads leave out an important detail — they have no power or water.

title.children: It's advertised as a 'resort-style paradise', but real estate ads ignore the fact it has no power or water

image.altText: An orange sun sets over a city skyline, casting orange light across the horizon

items.synopsis: New Zealand's economy has entered a recession, after the latest data confirmed the country has recorded two consecutive quarters of negative growth, while local investors await the release of the latest employment figures. Follow live.

title.children: New Zealand in recession as its economy shrinks, US pauses interest rate rises, ASX opens higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Capital Economics analyst Abhijit Surya has come out with one of the first notes on New Zealand's now confirmed recession. He says the March quarter decline of 0.1% was in line with analyst forecasts, but "markedly weaker" than what the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) expected. Surprisingly, private consumption and fixed investment both grew strongly in the quarter in the face of steep rate rises that have taken New Zealand's cash rate to 5.5%, among the highest in the developed world. " Private consumption grew by a solid 2.4% q/q [quarter on quarter], likely reflecting the confluence of a strong labour market, resurgent net overseas migration and a lower savings rate," Mr Surya noted. However, these GDP figures are from the first three months of this year, and Mr Surya says more recent data show household consumption is diving in New Zealand. "Indeed, it increasingly appears that activity will have weakened further in Q2," he noted. "According to StatNZ's monthly activity index, output growth slowed from 1.3% y/y in March to 0.7% in April. "Meanwhile, more timely data show that electronic card transactions fell by a sharp 2% m/m in May, which suggests private consumption is in fact on shaky ground." So, there's a good chance that NZ could be in for at least three consecutive quarters of economic contraction. The silver lining for Kiwis is that Capital Economics is expecting the recession to force the RBNZ to change tack and start cutting interest rates towards the end of this year. "As demand-side pressures on inflation continue to abate, the case for rate cuts will become increasingly compelling," Mr Surya argued.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NZ in recession and may stay there for a while longer

has come out with one of the first notes on New Zealand's now confirmed recession.
He says the
March quarter decline of 0.1%
was in line with analyst forecasts, but "markedly weaker" than what the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) expected.

Surprisingly, private consumption and fixed investment both grew strongly in the quarter in the face of steep rate rises that have taken New Zealand's cash rate to 5.5%, among the highest in the developed world.
Private consumption grew by a solid 2.4% q/q
[quarter on quarter], likely reflecting the confluence of a strong labour market, resurgent net overseas migration and a lower savings rate," Mr Surya noted.
Components of NZ GDP
(Capital Economics/Stats NZ)
However, these GDP figures are from the first three months of this year, and Mr Surya says more recent data show household consumption is diving in New Zealand.
"Indeed, it increasingly appears that activity will have weakened further in Q2," he noted.
"According to StatNZ's monthly activity index, output growth slowed from 1.3% y/y in March to 0.7% in April.
"Meanwhile, more timely data show that
electronic card transactions fell by a sharp 2% m/m in May
, which suggests private consumption is in fact on shaky ground."
So, there's a good chance that NZ could be in for at least three consecutive quarters of economic contraction.
The silver lining for Kiwis is that Capital Economics is expecting the recession to force the RBNZ to change tack and
start cutting interest rates towards the end of this year
"As demand-side pressures on inflation continue to abate, the case for rate cuts will become increasingly compelling," Mr Surya argued.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As expected, the ASX has opened up 0.2% this morning, sitting at 7,176 points as of 10:10am AEST. (For the latest figures, head to the post at the top of the page and expand it.) The gains are thanks to a 0.3% rise in the basic materials sector, while industrials have gained 0.1%. The other sectors are fairly flat in the early minutes of trade. The top five early movers are: BrainChip Holdings +2.4% Aurizon Holdings +2.4% Altium +1.3% BlueScope Streel +1.2% AUB Group +1% And the bottom five performers so far: Bellevue Gold -1.7% Allkem -1.2% Beach Energy -0.6% Ansell -0.3% Arema REIT No 1 -0.3%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens higher as investors wait for jobs figures

children.content: As expected, the ASX has opened up 0.2% this morning, sitting at 7,176 points as of 10:10am AEST. (For the latest figures, head to the post at the top of the page and expand it.)
The gains are thanks to a 0.3% rise in the basic materials sector, while industrials have gained 0.1%. The other sectors are fairly flat in the early minutes of trade.
The top five early movers are:
BrainChip Holdings +2.4%
Aurizon Holdings +2.4%
Altium +1.3%
BlueScope Streel +1.2%
AUB Group +1%
And the bottom five performers so far:
Bellevue Gold -1.7%
Allkem -1.2%
Beach Energy -0.6%
Ansell -0.3%
Arema REIT No 1 -0.3%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Economists aren't completely surprised that New Zealand has fallen into recession — in the lead up to today's data, it was a question of "when" not "if". Even the Reserve Bank of New Zealand had forecast that the country's economy would fall into a recession later this year. New Zealand's current cash rate sits at 5.5%, and their central bank had been aggressively hiking rates, in stark contrast to what we've seen in Australia. And now figures from Stats NZ show that most parts of the economy slowed, with business services hitting the brakes the most, falling 3.5%. "Management consulting, advertising, scientific, and engineering design services drove the fall in business services," said Stats NZ's Jason Attewell. The last time New Zealand experienced a recession was in September 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic, when it experienced its worst quarterly GDP fall on record. But New Zealand's economy bounced back out of the recession in the following quarter. You can read more about New Zealand's race to recession from business editor Ian Verrender below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's caused New Zealand to enter recession?

featuredLink.title: Why New Zealand is beating Australia in the race to a full-blown recession

children.content: Economists aren't completely surprised that New Zealand has fallen into recession — in the lead up to today's data, it was a question of "when" not "if".
Even the Reserve Bank of New Zealand had forecast that the country's economy would fall into a recession later this year.
New Zealand's current cash rate sits at 5.5%, and their central bank had been aggressively hiking rates, in stark contrast to what we've seen in Australia.
And now figures from Stats NZ show that most parts of the economy slowed, with business services hitting the brakes the most, falling 3.5%.
"Management consulting, advertising, scientific, and engineering design services drove the fall in business services," said Stats NZ's Jason Attewell.
The last time New Zealand experienced a recession was in
September 2020
due to the COVID-19 pandemic, when it experienced its worst quarterly GDP fall on record.
But New Zealand's economy bounced back out of the recession in the following quarter.
You can read more about New Zealand's race to recession from
business editor Ian Verrender
below:

image.altText: Plastic bags full of meth.

items.synopsis: Federal police have pulled off one of Australia's biggest drug busts, seizing six tonnes of liquid and crystal meth that was hidden in shipments of canola oil bottles destined for Melbourne.

title.children: Charges laid over failed attempt to import $1.7b worth of meth concealed in canola oil bottles

image.altText: A person with denim jacket and cap seen from behind sitting outdoors at a table looking at phone with laptop open.

items.synopsis: Most cryptocurrencies don't have a head office or a CEO, which makes regulating them tough. But expert Gavin Brown says ignoring their power is not an option.

title.children: 'This is dangerous': This expert says governments have their fingers in their ears about cryptocurrency

image.altText: Aboriginal people in a NT community - generic image

items.synopsis: Life outcomes for Indigenous Australians are continuing to worsen, as initiatives to Close the Gap offer mixed outcomes in the pursuit of ending systemic disadvantage.

title.children: Government says updated Closing the Gap data highlights need for structural change

image.altText: Young male migrants standing on a boat waiting for rescue.

items.synopsis: At least 79 migrants drown, with hundreds more said to be missing after their overloaded boat capsized and sank off Greece, in one of Europe's deadliest shipwrecks in several years.

title.children: At least 79 dead, hundreds more missing after Greece's deadliest shipwreck in years

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt leans over as though looking for something.

items.synopsis: The man who helped launch a fresh search for clues in a homicide investigation in the West Australian outback is hopeful his work might lead police towards answers.

title.children: Family friend who found 'jigsaw piece' to reignite outback murder probe hopes police can finish job

image.altText: Portrait photo of Salisbury councillor Severina Burner.

items.synopsis: Two members of the City of Salisbury council in Adelaide's north have been removed from their roles for not showing up to monthly meetings.

title.children: Controversial SA councillors removed at special meeting

image.altText: A truck dumping stuff on ground at farm.

items.synopsis: Libby Cooper's farm overlooks a picturesque river, but what's happening on a neighbouring area of land has her worried. And she is not the only one.

title.children: Fish kills and stinking fields: Is Tasmania overloaded with industrial rubbish?

image.altText: Xi Jinping smiles and holds a soccer ball while wearing a suit

items.synopsis: The Socceroos' friendly with world champions Argentina raises alarm bells and prompts a warning that Beijing is likely to exploit the match for propaganda.

title.children: Concerns grow over Socceroos match in China 'unwittingly being used for propaganda'

image.altText: A young man sits in a chair donating blood.

items.synopsis: An urgent blood delivery was made early on Monday to help treat those injured in a bus crash that killed 10 people, including members of the local AFL community. Now, players are working to replenish supplies.

title.children: Hunter Valley Aussie Rules community rallies to top up donor blood in wake of wedding bus crash

image.altText: a man with grey haior lying back in a hospital bed

items.synopsis: Darren Belling says the ambulance crew refused to take his wheelchair, which was sent separately in a taxi, and left outside his house for hours.

title.children: 'Stranded': Athlete left at hospital after ambulance refused wheelchair

image.altText: A bunch of Australian bank notes.

items.synopsis: A sharp increase in the number of complaints about delays in superannuation claims handling could be due in part to tougher economic circumstances, according to the peak body for the industry.

title.children: Super-payout delay complaints spike as cost of living 'increases urgency'

image.altText: A young girl with red hair tucked into bed, lying on her side and blowing her nose.

items.synopsis: With so much sickness floating around schools and daycare centres, runny noses are a common sight. So, when do your kids need to stay at home, and when can they go to school?

title.children: Does snot turn green when you're sick and run clear when you're well? We asked the experts

image.altText: A calico cat with orange, black and white fur in a bush.

items.synopsis: Halls Gap residents face a fine if caught with a cat as part of a ban that has spanned three decades.

title.children: This tiny town banned residents from owning cats 30 years ago to protect native wildlife. But did it work?

image.altText: A skull submerged in dirt.

items.synopsis: Archaeologists unearth mummy that is about 3,000 years old near the Peruvian capital of Lima.

title.children: Mummy reportedly dating back 3,000 years unearthed in Peru

image.altText: A general view of the Harvard Medical School, a square neoclassical building with six large columns.

items.synopsis: The Harvard Medical School morgue manager, his wife and several others face charges over allegations they stole body parts, including heads, brains, skin and bones, that were meant for education and research and sold them to people online for years.

title.children: Network of alleged US cadaver thieves used post to mail body parts around the country

image.altText: Russian President Vladimir Putin and Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko.

items.synopsis: Alexander Lukashenko says his country has started taking delivery of Russian tactical nuclear weapons, some of which he said were three times more powerful than the atomic bombs the US dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945.

title.children: Belarus starts taking delivery of Russian tactical nuclear weapons

image.altText: A large crowd is pictured surrounding a hearse that's in front of a cathedral.

items.synopsis: Devotees of former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi flock to Milan to say farewell to the controversial billionaire at a state funeral which closes a 30-year chapter in the country's history.

title.children: Thousands pay tribute as Silvio Berlusconi is laid to rest

image.altText: Ben Stokes sits and looks over his shoulder

items.synopsis: Ben Stokes is the answer to every question for England ahead of the Ashes, but what is the answer to persistent questions over the all-rounder's fitness?

title.children: England's talismanic leader has a huge question mark hanging over his head leading into this Ashes series

image.altText: Two men in blue shirts look on during a cricket training session.

items.synopsis: England receive a major boost for the opening Ashes Test at Edgbaston with two swing kings joined by Ben Stokes in the bowling attack.

title.children: Ashes boost for England as Stokes declared fit to bowl alongside Broad and Anderson

image.altText: Paul Frost arrives at the the Downing Centre District Court in Sydney.

items.synopsis: A jury delivers 43 guilty verdicts for a former swim coach and Masterchef finalist who abused 11 children at a south-west Sydney swimming school.

title.children: Swim coach and former MasterChef finalist guilty of 43 child sexual abuse charges

image.altText: A racing driver in his garage, wearing a cap, holds his finger in his ears to prevent noise.

items.synopsis: He is the current king of Formula 1 but Max Verstappen is already talking about stepping away. It is a possibility that F1's bosses should take notice of, writes Michael Doyle.

title.children: Max Verstappen is talking about F1 retirement, and his reasons should raise eyebrows
